title: Introduction to Cybersecurity
description: Learn the fundamentals of cybersecurity and common threats.

notes.content: Cybersecurity is the practice of protecting systems, networks, and programs from digital attacks. These cyberattacks are usually aimed at accessing, changing, or destroying sensitive information, extorting money from users, or interrupting normal business operations.

The CIA Triad is fundamental to cybersecurity:
• Confidentiality: Ensuring data is accessible only to authorized persons
• Integrity: Ensuring data is accurate and hasn't been modified
• Availability: Ensuring systems and data are accessible when needed

• Malware: Malicious software designed to harm or exploit systems
• Phishing: Fraudulent attempts to obtain sensitive information
• Ransomware: Software that locks your data until you pay
• DDoS Attacks: Overwhelming a system with traffic to make it unavailable

• Use strong, unique passwords for each account
• Keep software updated with latest security patches
• Enable two-factor authentication (2FA) where possible
• Regularly backup important data
• Be cautious with email attachments and links

title: Network Security
description: Understand networks, firewalls, and secure protocols.

notes.content: A network is a collection of computers and devices connected together to share resources. Network security involves protecting the integrity of a network and the data it contains from unauthorized access and misuse.

A firewall is a network security system that monitors and controls incoming and outgoing network traffic based on predetermined security rules. Types include:
• Packet filtering firewalls
• Stateful firewalls
• Application-layer firewalls
• Next-generation firewalls (NGFW)

A VPN creates a secure, encrypted tunnel for your internet traffic. Benefits include:
• Privacy from ISPs and networks
• Encrypted data transmission
• Access to restricted content
• Protection on public Wi-Fi networks

• HTTPS: Secure version of HTTP using SSL/TLS encryption
• SSH: Secure Shell for remote access
• TLS/SSL: Cryptographic protocols for secure communication
• IPSec: Suite of protocols for securing IP communications

title: Cryptography Basics
description: Master encryption, decryption, and digital signatures.

notes.content: Cryptography is the practice of using mathematical algorithms to encrypt and decrypt information. It ensures confidentiality, integrity, and authenticity of data transmission and storage.

Uses the same key for both encryption and decryption. Examples:
• AES (Advanced Encryption Standard)
• DES (Data Encryption Standard)
• Blowfish

Advantages: Fast, efficient for large amounts of data
Disadvantages: Key distribution challenges

Uses a pair of keys: public key (for encryption) and private key (for decryption). Examples:
• RSA
• Elliptic Curve Cryptography (ECC)
• DSA (Digital Signature Algorithm)

Advantages: Solves key distribution problem
Disadvantages: Slower than symmetric encryption

Hash functions produce fixed-size outputs from variable inputs. Common hashes:
• MD5 (deprecated)
• SHA-1 (deprecated)
• SHA-256 (secure)
• SHA-3

Digital signatures verify authenticity and non-repudiation of messages.

title: Ethical Hacking
description: Learn penetration testing and vulnerability assessment.

notes.content: Ethical hacking is the authorized practice of testing computer systems, networks, or applications for security vulnerabilities. It follows legal and ethical guidelines with explicit permission from the system owner.

1. Reconnaissance: Gathering information about the target
2. Scanning: Identifying open ports and services
3. Enumeration: Extracting detailed information
4. Exploitation: Attempting to gain unauthorized access
5. Post-Exploitation: Maintaining access and gathering data
6. Reporting: Documenting findings and recommendations

• Nmap: Network mapping and port scanning
• Metasploit: Penetration testing framework
• Burp Suite: Web application security testing
• Wireshark: Network packet analyzer
• Hydra: Brute force tool

• Always get written permission before testing
• Respect rules of engagement
• Protect confidential information
• Report vulnerabilities responsibly
• Follow applicable laws and regulations

title: Data Protection
description: Best practices for securing and managing data.

notes.content:
Classify data based on sensitivity:
• Public: No damage if disclosed
• Internal: Limited to organization
• Confidential: Restricted access, significant damage if disclosed
• Secret/Top Secret: Highest sensitivity, legal/regulatory implications

• Encrypt sensitive data at rest (storage) using AES-256
• Encrypt data in transit (transmission) using TLS/SSL
• Encrypt data in use with encrypted databases
• Key management is crucial for encryption effectiveness

• Principle of Least Privilege: Grant minimum necessary access
• Role-Based Access Control (RBAC): Access based on job roles
• Multi-Factor Authentication (MFA): Multiple verification methods
• Regular access audits to remove unnecessary permissions

• Follow 3-2-1 backup rule: 3 copies, 2 different media, 1 off-site
• Test backups regularly
• Use automated backup solutions
• Plan for disaster recovery scenarios
• Document recovery procedures
